subject: Greetings!
msgSnippet: I ve just discovered QuickScript while searching for a relatively easy-to-learn method of writing differently. My primary reasons for wanting a new way of
messageBody:
I've just discovered QuickScript while searching for a relatively
easy-to-learn method of writing differently. My primary reasons for
wanting a new way of writing is a) I tend to be wordy so an alphabet
that requires less work seems a blessing for my poor CTS-afflicted
right hand; and b) I recently discovered a co-worker reading my
planner in which I keep notes about work-related issues. Obviously,
I'd like to keep that stuff private as it is not always favorable and
the abbreviation of standard English I've started using doesn't seem
to suffice.

I'm only at the point of having skimmed through the manual and am
wondering how to start. What is the best way to learn QT? Are there
certain letters and combinations I should start with? Shall I learn it
the same way my 7-year-old is learning to write and spell (i.e.,
repetition in writing certain letter combinations).

Also, I'm thinking of learning this side-by-side with my 7-year-old.
She's very bright and loves to write. She's currently engrossed in
learning to write standard English and printing, and I wonder if it is
appropriate timing to try to teach her a new way to write as well, or
best to wait until she's more comfortable writing standard English? My
thought is that it'd be easier for her now than later, much like
learning a second language is easier when you're young. But I don't
want to confuse her and have her end up with poor marks in school,
which obviously is not going to encourage the use of QT as it may take
her focus off of the All-Important-Spelling. They keep saying they're
teaching her phonetically, but it doesn't really seem that way at times.

Ah, so many questions, but I have one more for now...

I am confused about the usage of No. 26 I-t. From what I'm seeing, it
seems to work for two sounds, a soft 'i' as in 'pit' (or the u sound
in busy) as well as a long 'ee' as in 'see' (or the y sound in busy)
and you are supposed to use No. 26 for the 'ee' sound made at the end
of words that end in 'y' such as busy? Is that correct? Does that mean
you would write 'pity' as 1-26-3-26 as opposed to 1-26-3-27? Why not
just use No. 27 EA-t which already represents this sound? Also, if No.
26 applies to 'ee' ending sound words that end in 'y' such as 'lovely'
or 'money' does it apply to words that end in 'ie' but have the same
sound, such as 'aerie' or 'freebie'? I'm guessing as QT is based on
pronunciation, not spelling, it would. Still, I don't get 26 instead
of 27.

I hope that's not too much for a first post, though I imagine it is.
As I mentioned previously, I am exceptionally verbose, unfortunately.

Anyway, nice to have found you all and I look forward to hearing your
thoughts.

-Ann
30-27 (?)
